message_1: If the mean height of a group of adults is 175 cm with a standard deviation of 10 cm, what is the probability of randomly selecting an adult from this group who is taller than 190 cm?
message_2:
To find the probability of randomly selecting an adult taller than 190 cm, we can use the z-score formula and the standard normal distribution table.

The z-score formula is:

z = (X - μ) / σ

where X is the value we're interested in (190 cm), μ is the mean (175 cm), and σ is the standard deviation (10 cm).

z = (190 - 175) / 10
z = 15 / 10
z = 1.5

Now, we look up the z-score of 1.5 in the standard normal distribution table, which gives us the probability of selecting an adult with a height less than 190 cm. The value for z = 1.5 is approximately 0.9332.

Since we want the probability of selecting an adult taller than 190 cm, we need to find the complement of this probability:

P(X > 190) = 1 - P(X < 190)
P(X > 190) = 1 - 0.9332
P(X > 190) ≈ 0.0668

So, the probability of randomly selecting an adult from this group who is taller than 190 cm is approximately 6.68%.
